posts.author: Maladus
posts.content:
Hello everyone, I've visited these forums several times over the years but have only just made an account because I'd like to see if you all can help me with a build for a new character concept that I want to play. The idea for this character is that he will be a Vhaeraun worshipping Drow Cleric. I was looking at the build listed here (http://nwnecbguild.forumer.com/topic/51 ... 1DrrJErJhE) and I like the feel of the concept, however Monk is out of the question because I cannot be a cleric of Vhaeraun and be a lawful alignment. Here are some other things to keep in mind:

1) PvM or PvP - Builds that are maximized for PvM are often not maximized for dueling with other PCs.
Balanced PvM and PvP; The character is a Drow and will likely see a bit of both.

2) Level cap - What is the maximum level that the build (or server) will likely reach?
30

3) Race preference - Unless a class demands a specific race or races, Human will be assumed. Otherwise, specify the your favorite.
Drow

4) Class preference - Describe which class(es) you have been considering so far and why. Your own concept is key to building what will do the job and be the most fun for you to play.
Cleric is a must, whatever else you use to fill out the build is up to you

5) Melee preference - A few options to consider are: dual-wielding vs. one-hand with shield, high AC dexterity-based vs. high-damage strength-based, sneak attacks (stealth), taunting, specialized attacks (e.g. whirlwind, knockdown, called shots, sneaks, death attacks... you name it!).
Dual-Wielding is preferred, but I know this can be hard with the restrictions

6) Range preference - DEX archery or Zen Archery (WIS)
Character will be mostly melee

7) Weapon preference - Which weapon type would you enjoy using the most?
Scimitar

8) Maximum item enhancement - In the setting where you intend to play this character, what is the highest enchantment (or bonus) that is likely to be used on equipment?
+3

9) Spellcasting - If you are requesting a build that is likely to use magic, explain its general use. Will it be used primarily to add enhancements to a physical base attack (i.e. for buffing), to cast strong offensive spells or a balance of both areas of expertise? If arcane-based, would you prefer to be able to cast spells reliably while wearing armor? Is indispellability of buffs an important consideration?
The build I'm looking for is to be a sort of Battlecleric, thus reaching level 9 or epic spells is not a necessity

10) Custom factors - Are there any special conditions that will affect how the build will work where you intend to play it? A PRC server is one example of a custom environment. Many servers have their own modifications to the standard game which will factor into the devising of a solid character build. Also, some community modules set their own rules
The server i paly on is Arelith, so the standard restrictions for that apply. The biggest of which is the 3 level rule where you must take at least 3 levels into the new class your plan to multiclass into before you can take levels in other classes.

Hopefully I have provided enough information to give you guys something to work with. I'll keep a close watch on this forum to answer any further questions that arise.

Thanks in advance!

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Maladus wrote:
When looking at the martial finessable weapons, I would go with rapier to get the increased critical threat range. Just out of curiosity, how would either of those two builds be when soloing?
Yah, for sword/board, probably the best choice unless you can buy Keen Edge scrolls, then handaxe's multiplier would prevail.  DWing needs either shorties for crit range or handaxes for multiplier (dmg) else the offhand AB penalty will be stiff.  Some DW players like hammers or maces for bludgeoning but there are so few races (like skels) that are painted with a specific damage resistance type, that it seldom produces much advantage in the long run.

I've soloed toons similar to these within SP & PW alike without much problem.  Once you get a few cleric levels in, the heavy work will lighten considerably.  At low levels I'll use the animated summon, slot some inflict spells (or other Neg nrg) to help heal it, do very well and risk little.  The trick is to let it (summon) cause as much damage as possible but unsummon before it makes a kill to protect your XP.  Eventually, most summons just get in the way anyway and alert hostiles before you are positioned properly.  Thoroughly explore the advantages of Darkness because it can help to control mobs very easily and all you need is Ultravision to pierce it before TruSee becomes available.

The way I set these sequences up accrues the maximum skills via early rogue but you could surely go heavy cleric and postpone rogue until later if you feel a higher level cleric is more comfortable in early going for you.  Fighter will raise your BAB quickly and provide the weapon choices you need... so you can only wait so long before the need to multiclass looms.  To fine-tune aspects of the build like the optimized sequence requires a detailed knowledge of the server, the CRs likely to be encountered in various regions, the equipment availability, etc.  Fortunately, a cleric is competent with strictly mundane gear which is the main class advantage in low- to mid-magic environs.

posts.content:
Maladus wrote:
Do you suffer a penalty when DW rapiers?

 
DWing rapiers is -4 mainhand and offhand with Ambi/TWF.  DWing light weapons (like shorties) is -2 MH/OH.  In a 40 cap build you m ight be able to focus in 2 weapons (medium/light) at once but is beyond the scope in this case.  BTW, you only need rapiers for DEX builds (i.e. finessed attack).  The penalty would be the same in a STR build DWing scimis (another non-light weapon), your preferred weapon. 

For PvM, it comes down to whether you feel you can hit the higher AC hostiles with that big of a penalty or not (divine buffs can only compensate so much).  Remember, in the early (low BAB) DW levels, -4 AB could end up resulting in up to 50% penalty (the multiclass limitation on Arelith discourages quick pre-epic attack power for 3/4 classes). Then again, you could just switch to sword/board and save the DWing for lesser opponents.  In PvP, though, -4 AB would be HUGE!  Combined with the standard -5 BAB progression, you'll be swatting and missing a lot with those extra attacks.

I assumed you wanted to maximize sneak opportunities via stealth so apologies.  Using Darkess you really don't need stealth in most cases so focus on detection.

Not being familiar with Arelith, you seem to have placed a priority on the Heal skill so I have incorporated it likewise.  For most environments, though, I would have shifted all those points over to Listen to help detect invisibles and hiddens approaching.  You would know better than I the relative value of those skills on your server.  But even ignoring the bias, you still should want the saves vs. spells as high as possible since this build is not structured for high-saves (my sheet shows F/W/R of 17/17/15 and 23/23/21 vs spells) but just barely enough.  Your divine buffs will help some as will scrolls of Protection from Spells (+8 vs. spells if available) but that is certainly not the focus of this build.

Blind Fight is possibly the singlemost important melee feat in existence.  Check the wiki description to get a better feel of what your toon will be exposing itself to without it.  TBH, I even started using the feat with my dedicated archers because they waste too much expensive ammo trying to hit shadows and other concealed types without it.  With that annoying drain touch attack looming, it's important to dispatch those races quickly.

UMD:  So are you telling me Arelith doesn't use the standard scroll check?  If it doesn't, you can get by with just enough for a value check and item valuation depends on the server.  Level 9 scrolls are usually somewhere in the 3k to 4K gold range which means a UMD of about modified 5 is plenty.  But that doesn't address the value of rods, wands and other more expensive magical items that might bolster your buffing potential.  The most important UMD advantage for a cleric is to gain access to mantles and even better... BREACHES!  It's the only way a non-arcanist has to lower enemy SR other than druid's Nature's Balance.  At Level 31, and with the standard scroll check in effect you will be able to cast spells by scroll up to Level 7.  Beyond that level, scrolls have a +5% extra failure rate per level (i.e. at UMD 31, a Level 9 scroll would have a 10% chance of fizzling dead when used).

TBH, this build, even with all those fighter levels, is still feat-starved in pre-epic (which is where you would be taking IKD, +save feats, skill focus, etc.).  A DP cleric needs to keep pre-epic BAB below 16 and any more fighter levels would put this toon over.  You really need all those I've outlined.  Extend for lengths for your primary buffs and Empower to boost your abilities as high as possible (Empowered Healing Circle is also very sweet around mobs of undead).  Nope.  I don't see any wiggle room which why I discarded the DEX version.  There is simply no room to insert Weapon Finesse without losing a crucial proficiency for most situations.  Now, a single hand option? Yes.  A few more feats to choose from.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
You actually have 17 extra points, not just 15, because having 32 Tumble isn't any more helpful than 30 points. With Tumble, you get +1 AC from every 5 base ranks in Tumble, not the net score, unlike Spellcraft or UMD. On the other hand, if you can get your Spellcraft to 33 (or 28), your net score would be a multiple of 5, which is what you need for another +1 to saves against spells.
My favorite place to dump left-over skill points is Lore, so I don't have to trek to a merchant and waste 100 old to identify something. Since you're on a PW, maybe a crafting skill would be nice.

EDIT: Ninja'd, and I forgot to answer the question about Blind Fight, but Hip has you covered there.

If Arelith doesn't use the hardcore scroll check then set UMD at whatever level is needed to use the equipment/wands you have your eye on. Since I have no idea how your server sets gold value for each property, only you can make that assessment.  Vanilla UMD uses 300K, 600K & 1M gold for levels 20, 25 & 30, respectively for class emulation.
